The Soviet lunar lander was a single stage craft? Well, not really. Actually, it was to have a descent stage that would take care of most of the breaking phase of the descent, then separate at about 13,000 ft. and crash on the moon’s surface. While it’s true that the same engine used for the ascent was also to be used for the actual landing, the lion’s share of the work was to be done by the “crash stage.”

I can imagine the Russians scratching their heads, even to this day, over the Saturn V. We build the world's largest launch vehicle, launch it thirteen times successfully, and then...just throw it away?
I read somewhere (but can't remember, unfortunately) that when the S-V first flew in 1967, the launch vehicle could have orbited a mass greater than everything the US had put into orbit up to that time.
You could do, and perhaps have done, an entire video on some of the plans and proposals for the Saturn V. (One concept would have strapped four of them together into one launch vehicle.)
One thing to remember about the S-V is that it was actually three rockets, built by competing corporations, stacked on each other. So the further development of the launcher would have required a high level of cooperation between them all. Without government contracts to create a market, there wasn't the incentive.
The TKS reminds me of the "Big Gemini" proposals, which might be worth a video itself.

Your statement that the Lunar Module Ascent Engine 'could only be started once--ever' is simply factually false.  The Ascent Engine was re-started on several flights (9,10,15, 16, and 17).  In addition, your statement that the Ascent Engine was 'never tested' is false.  The Ascent Engine was acceptance tested at Rocketdyne's Reno Field Laboratory in Reno, Nevada.  The company retains the acceptance test records and engine log books for the LM Ascent Engines.

The thing with Falcon 1 and  black arrow is, these are not about the actual thing actually going to orbit. Its about learning curves and craftmanship. Basically any person who starts physics or aviation studies would theoretically be able to build a rocket. But when you actually do it, all these things happen, like screws and plugs going loose from vibration and components melting due to overheating and so forth. So you spend loads of money for a bunch of people to go from "why is nothing happening on the launchpad?" to "whoah have you seen that explosion?" to "oopsie, go for orbit anyways!". Once they know how to handle that small rocket, they can go on to bigger ones or better ones. Even after 20 years of mothballing you can get the guys out of retirement and have them build a functional vehicle should the need arise.

Sending two landers that are capable of operating autonomously is actually genius. You could load up the second one with samples before launching in the first, permitting recovery of far more material. If the primary fails, you just leave the samples behind. It doesn't have to be wasted redundancy even if you are not going to the same place again.

The explosions of the N1 where kinda intentional. People often forget that the USSR had a completely different way to test their rockets and the engines. Instead of building complex Teststands, doing a lot of computer simulations or place mockups in a windtunnel. They just screwed an engine to a Tank or build an entire rocket and let it fly, waited to the expected explosion and fixed what caused (based on telemetry data) the explosion than tried again and so on.

For the N1 they actually planned 12 launches(/explosions) (without any crew) before ever going to the moon or even to orbit. They kinda wanted the failures.
The spectator at the first N1 launch where actually surprised that the rocket even got off the pad in the first place.

This also not actually that stupid to do back than computer simulations took much much longer an windtunnel can't simulate everything and building a Teststand which can withstand such a force is also not an easy task.

There is actually a great documentary which is partially about the N1 More about the (certainly superior) Engines of the N1 but still. It's called

The Engines That Came In From The Cold - And how The NK-33/RD-180 Came To The USA.

Great job on describing the LK lunar mission profile.  One more fun fact: as you stated, one LK would be landed uncrewed prior to the crewed lunar mission, and the crewed LK would use a pre-landed Lunakhod as a homing beacon - but if the engines on the crewed LK wouldn't light for the ascent, the cosmonaut could actually ride on the Lunakhod (it was designed for that) to the spare LK!  Additionally, the Lunakhod had photovoltaic panels for recharging its batteries.  It's strange to think these days that the Soviet lunar landing profile had more built-in redundancy than the U.S. profile, what with the political pressures which existed at the time (as evidenced by the risks which were taken with Voshkod, Soyuz 1, etc.).

Imagine if SpaceX would open a production line for the Falcon 1. That would be a direct competition to Electron and they may even be able to land the 1st stage of the rocket which could be a savings as well. Given that the 3rd iteration of the rocket would have double the capacity of the 2nd and with the Merlin 1D engine it would have even more thrust so it would easily outmatch Electron so it could be reusable very easily by cutting down the amount of payload.

Given that information they could also take on Minotaur rockets and the competition from Russia. In the end it would be a very interesting proposal for SpaceX if they want to reduce the cost of space flight but it does have one small issue. The second stage engine is currently not in production; however there is a solution, the Super Draco engine. If they put one of those engines on a second stage it would preform twice as effectively as the Kestrel but would have to be hypergolic instead of the RP-LOX that the Kestrel was. In the end it is an interesting idea they could do. As well as the fact it is designed to operate in Vacuum it makes some sense to use.

The issue of reusing of the 1st stage of the F1 would be engine throttling. Could the Merlin throttle far enough down is the question. As the only source I seen is a 40% of the thrust which would be too high for a F1 to land on unless they do the landing burn very late to cut velocity from the free fall.

The final item is the cost of the rocket launch. It appears the latest numbers they put up was 11 million or about double the Electron for over twice the launch capacity. It is very interesting idea as this does have merit but is this something SpaceX wants to use as a goal given their current focus.

The LK lunar lander was basically just the ascent stage. It used a blok d upper stage (the same one that is used with the proton rocket to this day) for orbit insertion of the L-1 spacecraft. After the cosmonaut did a spacewalk to the LK lander, it would detach from the bottom of the service module on the Soyuz-LOK. Then the almost all of the spacecrafts velocity would be shed from the blok d, before ejecting it to crash on the surface of the moon. From there the LK lander would fire it's engines and remove the last bit of velocity before landing. The rest of the mission was quite similar to Apollo. It used the lower portion of the spacecraft as a launch pad and went into orbit before preforming a rendezvous with the Soyuz-LOK. It would then dock (which could be done only once), the cosmonaut would spacewalk to the Soyuz-LOK and then it would ditch the lander and use the service module to leave lunar orbit.
